data.title: Minimap in default settings editor looks broken
data.body:
- Enable minimaps
- Open Settings editor
- Collapse all sections in Default settings editor or expand first and last section
- Minimap does not look good there.

Since default settings is not an editor completely and has collapsed regions it makes sense to not to show minimap for default settings

data.title: Cannot get types for vue, vuex in javascript
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->
I installed vue, vuex, because they provide their own type definitions, vscode don't give me any parameter info. how can I get type info in javascript
- VSCode Version:1.10.1
- OS Version:win10 1607

Steps to Reproduce:

1.npm install -S vue vuex
2.in jsconfig.json add typeAcquisition: {include: ['vue', 'vuex']}
but in my js file I cannot get any parameter info, please help me out

data.title: Not able to change keybinding for column select
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: v1.10
- OS Version: Windows 10 v1511 

Steps to Reproduce: 

1. Look in the default keybindings file for column select (by dragging)
2. I am unable to find it

Expected Result:
I am able to change the key binding for column select for example to just alt

Notes:
I do not mean the ctrl+shift+alt+<arrow key> bindings, I mean shift+alt+drag with the mouse style selection

data.title: Minimap: add a `alwaysShowViewport` setting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Currently the user is required to hover over the minimap to see the viewport.
A setting which keeps the viewport visible at all time would greatly improve my minimap experience. Something like:

```JSON
"editor.minimap.alwaysShowViewport": true
```

data.title: Debug with Nodejs and nodemon keep getting restart upon 'Attach to Process'
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: Mac 10.12.3
- Node Version: 6.10.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch a node process in console with nodemon `nodemon --debug server.js`
2. Click `Attach to Process` in vcode.
3. The server will be restarted by nodemon even though no files are changed
4. vcode throws and error: `Request 'evaluate' was cancelled because Node.js is unresponsive.`

Before this release the nodemon wasn't detecing changes all the workflow was fine. Now if the server is slow to start I cannot attach vscode to it. I tried to use the timeout option in launch.json with no luck.

data.title: Add confirmation for folders and files movement in File Tree
data.body:
Some of developers accidentally move folders or files in another folder when inaccurate trying to open some file or expand folder (by moving mouse when doing action).
And sometimes he can just revert it using git or trying to find it manually.

It will be good to add optional prompt for confirmation for this actions. In future some of extensions can subscribe to this actions to perform refactoring (by changing paths in dependent components).

data.title: Merge objective-c and objective-cpp again?
data.body:
#21599 added a new language 'Objective-c++' with 'objective-c++' as language id.

Having two different languages 'objective-c' and 'objective-cpp' adds some benefits, such as the possibility of separate providers/snippets for each 'flavour', but also breaks existing extensions that so far contributed just to 'objective-c' and were enabled on both m and mm files.

There are only few objective-c extensions. If we decide to keep going with two language ids, we should contact these extensions.

data.title: Remove '+' from objective-c++ language id.
data.body:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/21599 added a new language 'Objective-c++' with 'objective-c++' as language id.
We should avoid special characters in language id. I suggest to change it to 'objective-c++' , following the 'cpp' language id for C++

data.title: Unexpected breakpoint behaviour after changing code with breakpoint
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.0
- OS Version: Win10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set a breakpoint
2. Type some text on the line with breakpoint

Additional inline breakpoint at the beginning of the line appears.

![additional breakpoint](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2239563/23509976/0d352e7c-ff58-11e6-860e-166c0912095b.gif)

Removing the new text does not bring the breakpoint away.

data.title: Unexpected behaviour on quote wrapping

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: Mac OS X El Capitain

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write foo, unquoted.
2. Select foo
3. Type "
    (It will become "foo")
4. Type [arrow right] to move the cursor away from the selection 
   (it will become "fo"")

Coming from atom, I expected it to just be "foo". It quickly becomes an annoyance as I have to always get back and correct it.

Also:

1. Type " 
    ("" will show, with the cursor in the between the quotes)
2. Type a 
   (it will become ä", which I believe is not the desired result in any circumstance. It should be just ä or "a" - for me at least, the second option would be the most useful)

data.title: [suggestion] There should be a "Goto Next Change" in diff view

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: ANY
- OS Version: ANY

Just like the <kbd>F8</kbd> key for jumping to next error/warning, the git (scm) diff view should also have a goto next / previous change. With the new `Stage Selected Ranges` command, I can use partially use my keyboard for committing, so this feature would improve that experience.

data.title: Typescript - "Add Missing Import" Quick Fix not available in TSX markup
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.0
- OS Version: Windows 7 SP1 64-bit

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add a Typescript React TSX file to a React Typescript Workspace
2. Add contents similar to that below, such that an imported `Component` is used in TSX markup
3. Comment-out the `import` statement for `ContactForm`, to test Quick Fix
4. Right-click the squiggled word `ContactForm` in the `render` method

**Expected behaviour**
Quick Fix to `Add Missing Import` is offered in a context menu

**Actual Behaviour**
No Quick Fix is offered for the missing TSX `ContactForm` reference.

_Note: Quick Fix works nicely for `ContactFormData`, which is referenced in non-TSX code._

```typescript

import * as React from 'react';
import { Dispatch } from 'redux';
import ContactForm, { ContactFormData, ContactFormProps } from './ContactForm';

export interface ContactPageProps {
}

class ContactPage extends React.Component<ContactPageProps, {}> {

    save(values: ContactFormData, dispatch: Dispatch<{}>, props: ContactFormProps) {
        // tslint:disable-next-line:no-console
        console.log('ContactPage.save');
        // tslint:disable-next-line:no-console
        console.log(values);
    }

    render() {
        return (
            <ContactForm onSubmit={this.save} />
        );
    }
}

export default ContactPage;
```

data.title: Option to set spaces after/before braces in import statements typescript
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Currently when i use quick fix "Add missing import" (which is totally awesome feature) i get 
`import { Something } from 'something'`
2. It would be nice to have option to specify whether put spaces after `{` and before `}` braces, so i could get 
`import {Something} from 'something'` without spaces

Thank you for great job
